[Reference Story]: Dixon was cleaning his rifle when a stern voice asked "Are you the replacement"?


He looked up to see Sergeant Hartford before him and nodded.

"Good," Hartford said curtly. "Leave your rifle and come with me".

When they stepped out of the dugout and made their way through the boggy trenches it was darker than Dixon remembered it being and he found it hard to adjust to the light.

"You know why you're here?" Hartford asked to break the silence.

"No" Dixon answered. "They didn't want to give me the specifics. All they said was I should ask you and that I'd be having a long night ahead of me".

Hartford chuckled softly. "Fuckers.. Alright I'll make this simple".

They then stopped at a ladder propped up against the trench line and he pointed at a dead corpse stuck on a string of barbed wire between them and the enemy trenches.

"You see the stiff over there?" Hartford asked.

"Murray". Dixon corrected him. "I knew him, his name was Murray".

"It doesn't matter" Hartford answered. "He's dead now and command wants us to get him and his friends off that wire and out of sight from our men. They say it damages the morale".

Dixon stared at Murray's cold dead eyes that pierced through the darkness and nodded. He had several friends that didn't make it back from the previous attack and he now understood why his superiors didn't tell him the details about his assignment.

"Anyways you don't have to bury them or anything, just take them off the wires so they can't be seen. We'll use the moon as our only source of light and divide ourselves. You'll be going West and I'll be East and we'll meet back here in five minutes, understood?"

Dixon nodded and Hartford stuck a pair of wire cutters in his hand and removed his helmet while Dixon did the same before he asked "What do I do if they're still alive? The attack only happened a few hours ago. I've heard stories that men can rot out there for days on that wire."

Hartford only shook his head. "Don't make yourself a target. Just take care of the bodies and get back safe. I don't want to bury another replacement".

With that Hartford rubbed some mud on his face and crawled out of the trench and Dixon did the same a moment later.

It was hard at first. The stench from the bodies made Dixon gag and the flies were annoyed that someone was interrupting their meal. But the worst part at all was looking at them.

But by the third body, Dixon just shut his nose and nearly ripped them off the wire without so much as even glancing at their faces.

He then came to the last one in his sector and put the wire cutter to the man's arm when the living man jerked and shouted.

Dixon panicked and hit the ground as the man began to plead in the darkness. "Please! Please help me!"

Dixon slid his hand over the man's mouth. "It's okay I'm here.. Listen, I'm going to get you out of here but you have to be quiet."

The man agreed and did his best to be quiet when Dixon began to cut him from the barbed wire. But the pain of flesh ripping from metal made him nearly scream in anguish and Dixon tried his best to calm him down.

"Hey, do you have a family?" Dixon asked as he finished tearing his leg off the wire.

The man nodded "I have two daughters.. Oh my God, I've barely thought about them all this time. Listen, you have to tell them I love them if I don't make it out of here."

Dixon stared at the enemy trench line as he held his breath for a moment and then kept cutting "Tell them yourself when you get out of here."

He then ripped his other leg away and the man screamed in pain again as a sniper's bullet ripped into the ground beside them.

Dixon dropped the wire cutters and cussed his bad luck before helping the man to his feet but he shook his head. "I can't walk.. I can't feel my legs."

The sniper's aim got better and a bullet struck the post next to Dixon's head as he picked the man up and carried him.

Cold blood began leaking all over his back as Dixon ran and more shots rang out in the night.

"You're going to be okay I promise. Just think about your daughters we're almost there." Dixon tried to comfort the man as more blood ran down his back.

The sentry at the trench line began shooting back at the sniper and Dixon nearly collapsed as they fell into the trench where Hartford was there waiting for him.

"What happened?" He asked angrily. "Are you okay?"

Dixon immediately stood up and grabbed the man's hand to drag him. "Give me a hand, this man needs to see a medic immediately or he's going to die".

Hartford flipped over the man's corpse and shook his head. "You've wasted your time. I'm sorry but this man's already dead."

Dixon looked down and saw a fresh bullet wound through the man's neck and his cold dead eyes staring back at him.

"I promised him he'd be okay," Dixon said staring at his hands that were now caked in blood.

Hartford patted Dixon on the back and knelt beside him. "I can take care of him. Get to a dressing station and clean yourself off".

Dixon did as he was told and slumped off to the rear trench line as Hartford checked the man's body and found a set of ID tags and a photograph of two little girls with an address scribbled on the back.

"Great". He muttered. "One more letter I have to mail out."

He then slid the photograph in his uniform next to the others."

Dixon felt a cold wind tunnel through the dugout, whistling a hollow, mournful tune. The air itself seemed to hold its breath, waiting. A voice, flat and disembodied, cut the silence. "You the replacement?" 

He lifted his gaze, the rifle stock cold against his cheek. A figure stood silhouetted against the sickly yellow light filtering from above. Sergeant Hartford. His face, an indistinguishable blur in the gloom, held a knowing, almost predatory smile.

"Leave the toy soldier behind," Hartford rasped, his voice like dry leaves skittering across cobblestones.

They emerged from the dugout into a world swallowed by shadow. The trenches, slick with mud and shimmering with an unearthly luminescence, seemed to writhe, alive and hostile. Even the moon, a pale, sickly disc, seemed to cast down a gaze devoid of pity.

Dixon felt a weight settle on his chest, a leaden sense of wrongness that made his breath catch in his throat. He couldn't remember this darkness, this suffocating, all-consuming gloom.

"They didn't tell me much," Dixon mumbled, his voice swallowed by the oppressive silence. "Just that I should ask you. And... that I'd be having a long night." 

Hartford chuckled, a sound that scraped against Dixon's nerves. "Those bastards," he spat, the word a curse against the very air they breathed. "Alright. Simple enough."

He gestured towards a ladder, its rusted rungs groaning like tortured souls. Above, strung between the barbed wire and the enemy trenches, hung a grotesque tapestry of bodies. A chilling tableau against the night sky.

"Recognize him?" Hartford's voice was a whisper, the question almost an afterthought.

Dixon stared at the twisted figure, the pale, lifeless face staring back with hollow accusation. "Murray," he breathed, the name escaping his lips like a prayer.

"Doesn't matter," Hartford said, his voice flat, devoid of emotion. "He's gone. Command wants them... cleaned up. Says it's bad for morale."

Dixon felt a coldness creep into his bones, a chilling certainty that this task was more than just a duty. It was a descent into an abyss, a nightmare with no waking. He looked at the bodies, the stark testament to the futility of war, and understood why they hadn't told him the details.

"Just take them off the wire," Hartford continued, his voice echoing in the uncanny silence. "No need for formalities. We'll use the moon. You head west, I'll go east. Five minutes, understood?"

Dixon nodded, accepting the grim duty like a sentence. Hartford pressed a pair of wire cutters into his hand, the cold metal a stark contrast to the warmth of his own blood. They removed their helmets, the act a stripping bare of all pretense, leaving them vulnerable under the unforgiving gaze of the night.

As Dixon crawled out of the trench, the stench hit him first. A suffocating miasma of decay and desperation. Then the buzzing, a relentless, droning symphony of flies feasting on the dead. He tried to focus on the task at hand, to shut out the whispering wind and the gnawing fear that coiled in his gut.

But each body, every contorted face, every lifeless eye, chipped away at his sanity. The line between living and dead blurred, until it felt as though he himself was fading, becoming part of the grotesque tableau.

And then he saw him.

The one who was still alive.

He was clinging to the barbed wire, his face contorted in a silent scream. Dixon froze, his breath caught in his throat. The man's eyes, wide and pleading, locked onto his, shattering the illusion of normalcy.

"Please," the man rasped, his voice a dry, rattling whisper. "Please help me."

Panic surged through Dixon. He scrambled back, his own fear drowning out the man's pleas.

"Quiet!" he hissed, his voice shaking. "Just be quiet."

He pressed his hand over the man's mouth, stifling the desperate gasps.

"I'm going to get you down," Dixon said, his voice strained, more a promise to himself than to the man. "Just be quiet. Think about your family."

The man nodded weakly, tears streaming down his grime-streaked face.

"I have daughters," he whispered, his voice trembling. "Two little girls..."

Dixon, his heart pounding against his ribs like a trapped bird, began to cut the wire. The man cried out, a strangled sob, as the rusted metal tore through flesh.

"They need you," Dixon muttered, trying to convince himself as much as the dying man. "Tell them you love them. Tell them..."

But even as he spoke, the world tilted. A sharp crack, the whine of a bullet slicing through the night. The man went limp in his arms, his fading breaths a hollow echo in the stillness.

Dixon looked up, his blood running cold. A sniper. Hidden in the enemy trench, its sights trained on him.

He scrambled back, dragging the dead weight with him, the stench of blood and gunpowder filling his nostrils. More shots rang out, each one a hammer blow against his sanity.

"We're almost there," he gasped, his voice hoarse, his lungs burning.

He stumbled into the trench, collapsing beside Hartford.

"What took so long?" Hartford demanded, his voice sharp, his face shadowed.

Dixon pointed to the body, to the lifeless eyes staring accusingly at the moonlit sky.

"He was...alive," he choked out, the enormity of what had happened crashing down on him.

Hartford knelt beside the body, a detached curiosity in his eyes. He turned it over, revealing a gaping wound in the man's chest.

"Dead already," he said, his voice flat. "You wasted your time."

Dixon stared at the dead man, at the fresh wound, the blood still staining his hands crimson. He felt a cold emptiness spread through him, a chilling realization of the absurdity of it all.

"I promised him," he whispered, the words a broken lament into the dark.

He looked up at Hartford, his eyes pleading for understanding. But the seargeant's face remained impassive, a mask hiding the abyss of indifference that lurked beneath.

Hartford patted Dixon on the shoulder, a gesture devoid of comfort.

"Just another letter to write," he muttered, his gaze traveling to the man's lifeless face.

He reached into the man's pocket, pulling out a crumpled photograph. Two little girls, their faces beaming with innocent joy.

Hartford tucked the photograph into his uniform pocket, next to the others. The faces of the dead, forever frozen in time.

Dixon watched him, the weight of their shared secret settling heavily on his shoulders. He felt lost, adrift in a world where death and absurdity reigned supreme, and the only truth was the cold, indifferent gaze of the moon.

[Reference Story]: Cabinets were opening and slamming shut in the kitchen again. Grant didn't have time for this. His deadline was in ten hours.


"Kitchen's closed!" He yelled at the ghost. "It's not good for you to eat in the middle of the night! You'll get fat!"

The sounds stopped.

The simple wooden desk in his bedroom was a mess of papers, but he knew where everything was. His lamp began to flicker erratically, so he turned on the overhead light.

There had been multiple busy news cycles, and he had been burning the candle at both ends for months. Grant told himself that it was worth tolerating this for the cheap rent. It was too late to regret taking out student loans for a journalism degree.

So far, he'd been unable to convince even a single person other than his landlord that he was being obnoxiously haunted. On the rare occasions women stayed overnight, they thought he had set up some elaborate, poor taste prank and never spoke to him again.

He rewrote his last paragraph until he was happy with it. The opener was a little sensationalist for the fairly respectable publication employing him, so he fixed it.

The feeling that someone was looking over his shoulder was unshakable. He already had an editor like that and was annoyed.

Finally submitting his article at 3 am was a relief. There was still a little of the scotch his brother had gifted him for his birthday, so he poured a few shots in the nicest glass that had not yet been smashed by the stupid ghost.

Someone knocked decisively at the door. He was shocked to open it and discover it was the police. He had just submitted a scathing article regarding their handling of a recent peaceful protest, and in his slightly inebriated state wondered how they had found out so fast.

"Your neighbors called in a noise complaint. What's going on?"

Grant felt that explaining that it was just the ghost lacked a certain something, so he told them the TV had been turned up loud, and it was off now.

That was apparently acceptable.

------

His landlord, who lived in the apartment above him, came to check on him the next morning. He was awake. He remembered sleep fondly from his youth.

It was necessary to move some books and papers off the kitchen table to sit and have a cup of coffee with Mrs. Hawke. He often felt that his cheerful, yellow kitchen was completely inappropriate, but it was three bus transfers to a store that sold paint. An unregarded wall clock ticked away time, oblivious to daylight savings. The only thing required of it was to count twelve minutes for hard boiled eggs, but one day it would be accurate again.

"The ghost was slamming shut cabinet doors, and someone called in a noise complaint. That's why the cops came."

Mrs. Hawke was not without sympathy. Most people only saw as far as her stern, steel gray bun and plain clothing, failing to notice her compassionate, warm brown eyes past her resting bitch face.

"How is that going? Is there anything I can do?"

"Research is ongoing," he said. "I'm having a difficult time finding a good source. Mostly what people have to say about ghosts sounds insane. Do I sound like that when I try to tell other people?"

She took a sip of her coffee, but it was still a little too hot, so she set it down.

"Probably, honestly. I hope you're not unhappy. You've lasted longer here than anyone ever has before."

Grant stirred some creamer into his sturdy mug, just happy he had Maxwell House at this point.

"I honor my commitments. You did outright tell me this place is haunted up front. I just didn't believe you at the time. Have you tried anything to get rid of the ghost?"

Mrs. Hawke said, "Well, I tried to burn some sage, but it only triggered my asthma. Then, me and my nephew tried to cast the spirit out with a passage from the Bible, but he's an atheist, and I'm agnostic. Our hearts just weren't in it. It was kind of embarrassing, and then the bookmark fell out, so we just kind of left."

This was not extremely helpful.

------

He met Luka by chance, and couldn't help but want to spend any free moment with her.

Grant thought that Luka was the most beautiful woman he'd ever seen. Luka thought that crystals and random plants had mystical healing powers. He had finally found someone who believed him. He seemed to spend a lot of time trying to convince her to stop shoving all his garlic in her ears to treat her ear infection, but he was actually really happy dating her.

One night the ghost was tossing around the furniture, and Luka intervened.

"Hey, it's ok. Everyone gets angry," she said, "I mean, this morning the dryer tore holes in my favorite leggings, and I was pretty angry. You're damned to wander the earth in eternal torment, and you're pretty angry. I mean, I understand."

Grant was shocked when the ghost spoke for the first time, with a bold man's voice.

"Is this bitch for real?"

Luka seized the opportunity to open a dialouge, earnestly telling the ghost about the cosmic harmony of the universe, nature, and the importance of feelings and expression.

"I'm moving in at the end of the month," she said, "and I'm sure we'll be great friends, and talk about these things a lot."

Again, a voice came from nowhere.

"I'm out."

It took a while for Grant to feel sure that the ghost was gone, but it was never an issue again. Mrs. Hawke brought Luka a vegan carrot cake and expressed her heartfelt gratitude."

Ten paltry hours until the deadline loomed, a monstrous spectre in the dim, flickering light of his desk lamp.

"Kitchen's closed!" he roared, his voice cracking with a desperation that bordered on hysteria. "Closed, you hear? Not a morsel for the spectral appetite in the dead of night! You'll be plump as a bishop, you will, with your midnight feasts."

Grant, he was a man of words, cursed with a reality that seemed determined to mock his every attempt at constructing a coherent narrative.

The ghost. The bloody, maddening ghost.

But who could believe in ghosts? In the age of reason and cynicism, who would dare indulge in such fanciful notions?

He rewrote the opening paragraph, trimming the sensationalism, polishing the prose until it gleamed with the deceptive sheen of objectivity. A flicker of doubt, a whisper of self-reproach, gnawed at the edges of his mind.

Was he losing his grip?

The feeling of being watched, scrutinized, intensified. An unseen presence, a weight settling upon his shoulders, a chilling reminder of his spectral housemate. It was as if the editor, a man whose gaze could wither a budding sunflower, had materialized in the room, his hawk-like eyes boring into Grant's soul.

Finally, at the witching hour, three a.m., the article, his article, was complete. A triumph of will over exhaustion, a testament to the intoxicating allure of a deadline met.

He poured a generous measure of scotch, a gift from his brother, a man who believed in ghosts only when they came in the form of bad investments. The glass, a survivor of numerous ghostly tantrums, glinted in the dim light.

A sharp rap on the door, a jarring intrusion into his hard-won solitude. His heart hammered against his ribs, a frantic drumbeat in the silence.

The police? Had his scathing exposé of the local constabulary's handling of the recent protest sparked a retaliatory visit?

He opened the door, a wave of apprehension washing over him.

It was the police, their faces grim, their expressions unreadable.

"We had a noise complaint," the officer stated, his voice flat, devoid of inflection.

Grant stammered, his mind racing for a plausible explanation.

"The television, officer," he blurted out, "it was... it was a bit loud. My apologies, it's off now."

They seemed satisfied, their gaze lingering for a moment on the chaotic tableau of his apartment before they turned and walked away.

Relief, sharp and sweet, surged through him. He closed the door, leaning against it, his breath coming in ragged gasps.

The next morning, Mrs. Hawke, his formidable landlady, appeared at his door, her face a mask of weary understanding. She was a woman carved from granite, her steel-gray bun a testament to her stoicism, her eyes, though, those brown eyes held a flicker of warmth, a hint of sympathy for the tortured soul who rented the apartment below.

"The ghost, dear boy," she said, her voice a low rumble, "it seems to have taken a liking to slamming cabinet doors. The neighbors complained."

Grant sighed, a weary sound. "I tried explaining," he said, "but..."

"I know," she interrupted, her gaze unwavering. "It's best not to dwell on such things.

Grant, with a weariness that settled deep in his bones, returned to his desk, the ghosts of deadlines past and present looming over him.

He had found Luka, a beacon of light in the dreary landscape of his existence. She believed. She truly believed in the spectral denizens of his apartment.

She spoke to the ghost, not with fear, but with a gentle understanding, a shared knowledge of the unseen world.

And then, the ghost spoke.

A voice, deep and resonant, echoing through the empty rooms.

"Is this bitch for real?"

Luka, undetertered, continued her dialogue with the ghost, weaving tales of cosmic harmony and the importance of expressing one's feelings.

"I'm moving in at the end of the month," she announced, her voice unwavering.

"I'm out," the ghost grumbled, and silence descended once again upon the apartment.

Grant felt a weight lift from his shoulders, a sense of peace he hadn't known in years.

Mrs. Hawke, a rare smile gracing her lips, presented Luka with a vegan carrot cake, a gesture of gratitude for the unexpected exorcism.

And Grant, finally free from the shackles of his spectral roommate, sat down at his desk, ready to face the world, and the deadlines, with a renewed sense of purpose. The words flowed, unburdened by the weight of the unseen, the ghosts of the past receding into the shadows, replaced by the promise of a brighter future.
